application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is concerned with finite-time L 2 leaderfollower consensus of networked Euler-Lagrange systems in the presence of external disturbances. A distributed finite-time L 2 control protocol is proposed by using backstepping design such that a group of follower agents modeled by Euler-Lagrange systems can follow a desired leader agent and achieve leaderfollower consensus in finite time. Moreover, the finite-time L 2 gain is less than or equal to a prescribed value. A simulation example of a network composed of seven two-link manipulators is given to show the effectiveness of the theoretical results.
control protocol such that a group of follower agents can track the leader. We refer readers to the recent surveys [3], [15], [16] on more results concerning consensus of multiagent systems.

Motivated by the fact that the dynamical behavior of some physical systems can be modeled by Euler-Lagrange systems, such as electrical systems and robotic manipulators, a large number of researchers pay attention to consensus of networked Euler-Lagrange systems, which is more challenging as existing results of linear systems fail to deal with Euler-Lagrange systems due to the intrinsic nonlinearity. In [17], synchronization of networked Euler-Lagrange systems was investigated based on sampled data. In [18], a distributed adaptive control was utilized to solve the containment consensus problem of Euler-Lagrange systems. In the case of the leader-follower consensus, a command generator known as the leader provides the desired reference trajectory. All followers are forced to track the trajectory of the leader. Much effort has been made in forcing networked Euler-Lagrange systems to track a desired leader. In [19], the problem of tracking control of networked Euler-Lagrange systems is studied in a switching network by utilizing distributed adaptive control. In [20], sliding mode control was applied to synchronize all following Euler-Lagrange systems with a dynamical leader. In [21], a continuous tracking algorithm with adaptive updating laws of coupling gains was proposed to solve the synchronization problem of leader-follower Euler-Lagrange systems. As the convergence rate is a critical performance index to evaluate the effectiveness of the control algorithm, how to design an appropriate control protocol to improve the convergence rate is important. Finite-time convergence, which ensures consensus to be achieved after a certain period of time, is in great demand. In comparison with asymptotic consensus protocols in [17]- [22], finite-time consensus is more practical, yet more challenging.

Distributed finite-time control algorithms for multiagent systems were proposed in [23]- [25] based on the finite-time stability theory. In [23], leader-follower consensus of linear second-order multiagent systems was considered. An observerbased control algorithm was designed to track a dynamical leader in finite time. However, the result is applicable only for linear systems. Later, a second-order sliding-mode observer was proposed in [24] for a group of Euler-Lagrange systems with a dynamical leader. In [25], the problem of the finite-time containment consensus of networked Euler-Lagrange systems with control torque constraints was discussed. On the one hand, the upper bound of the settling time is still unknown in [23] and [24]. On the other hand, the effect of disturbances is not taken in account. In fact, there often exist many different forms of disturbances in practical environments, such as external interferences, stochastic process, and measurement noises. These factors will result in performance deterioration, such as instability, slow convergence rates. It is essential to study the finite-time consensus problem in the presence of external disturbances. In [26], a finite-time bounded controller was designed for delayed conic-type nonlinear systems with mismatched disturbances. In [27], discontinuous and continuous integral sliding mode control protocols were proposed, respectively, to solve finite-time consensus of linear second-order multiagent systems in the existence of bounded disturbances. As adaptive control is an effective way to adjust parameters [28], in [29], the finite-time consensus problem of networked Lagrange systems with external disturbances was solved by using sliding-mode control and adaptive control. While in [30], an adaptive protocol with distributed updating laws was proposed by combining the disturbance compensator technique in a directed network of Euler-Lagrange systems with bounded external disturbances. Effective methods are presented in [26], [27], and [29] to eliminate disturbances, which may suffer the chattering effect. H ∞ control provides us an another option to deal with disturbances. From the perspective of H ∞ performance [31]- [34], backstepping control has been used to study consensus of networked Euler-Lagrange systems with external disturbances [35]. However, these works [33]- [35] restrict their scope with asymptotic consensus. Thus, how to design a suitable distributed finitetime control protocol for networked Euler-Lagrange systems to ensure finite-time leader-follower consensus and attenuate the effect of disturbance at an acceptable level serves as the motivation of this paper.

This paper focuses on finite-time L 2 leader-follower consensus of networked Euler-Lagrange systems in the presence of external disturbances. First, a virtual error variable is defined for every follower based on an auxiliary function including both discontinuous and continuous distributed control protocols. Then in a backstepping framework, the original error systems between the leader and the followers are transferred into systems related with the virtual error variables. By defining a performance vector, finite-time L 2 consensus is analyzed based on the finite-time stability theory. A sufficient condition is derived ensuring leader-follower consensus in finite time. In the meanwhile, the finite-time L 2 gain of the disturbance attenuation is made less or equal than a prescribed value. The upper bound of the settling time is also given. The case without external disturbances is also discussed. Finally, a network of seven two-link manipulators are given to validate the effectiveness of theoretical results.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: in Section II, the problem formulation is given and some preliminaries are presented. Section III gives sufficient conditions for finite-time L 2 consensus of networked Euler-Lagrange systems. Section IV presents a numerical example. The conclusion is drawn in Section V. Throughout this paper, for a given vector
div.formula: x = [x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ] T and a scalar α > 0, sig(x) α = [|x 1 | α sgn(x 1 ), |x 2 | α sgn(x 2 ), . . . , |x n | α sgn(x n )] T , x α = [x α 1 , x α 2 , . . . , x α n ]
div.p: T , and sgn(x) = [sgn(x 1 ), sgn(x 2 ), . . . , sgn(x n )] T , where sgn(•) denotes the signum function, • denotes either the Euclidean vector norm or its induced matrix two-norm and "⊗" denotes the Kronecker product.

div.head: A. Graph Theory
div.p: Consider a group of leader-follower agents labeled by 1, 2, . . . , n + 1. The agent indexed by n + 1 is known as the leader and other agents are indexed by 1, 2, . . . , n, which are referred to as the followers. Graphs are used to describe an interconnected topology of these n + 1 agents. The directed graph G = (V, E) is with a set of nodes V = {1, . . . , n + 1} and edges E ∈ V × V, where (i, j) ∈ E denotes the allowed information flow from node i to node j. There are no selfloops in the graph. A path from node j to node i is a sequence of edges, (j, p 1 ), (p
div.formula: 1 , p 2 ), . . . , (p l , i) with distinct nodes p k , k = 1, 2, . . . , l. A graph is connected if there is a path between any of nodes. A = [a ij ] n×n is the adjacency matrix with a ij = 1 if (j, i) ∈ E; otherwise, a ij = 0. The set N i = {j | (j, i) ∈ E} denotes the neighbors of node i.
div.p: The Laplacian matrix L = (l ij ) n×n associated with an adjacency matrix A is defined by l ii = n+1 j=1 a ij and l ij = -a ij , i = j, i, j = 1, 2, . . . , n + 1. Then L can be written as
div.formula: L = L 1 b 0 1×n 0 , L 1 ∈ R n×n , b ∈ R n .
div.p: Assumption 1: The network of followers is undirected. The leader has a path to every follower.

div.head: B. Problem Statement
div.p: Consider a network of multiple Euler-Lagrange systems. The ith Euler-Lagrange system is described by
div.formula: M i (q i )q i + C i (q i , qi )q i + g i (q i ) = τ i + δ i , i = 1, 2, . . . , n(1)
div.p: where q i ∈ R m is the generalized configuration coordinate; M i (q i ) ∈ R m×m is the inertia matrix; C i (q i , qi ) ∈ R m×m is the Coriolis/centripetal matrix; g i (q i ) ∈ R m is the vector of gravitational torques, τ i ∈ R m is the vector of control input torques; and δ i ∈ R m is a term that includes an external disturbance. For typical mechanical systems, the inertia matrix M i (q i ) are symmetric positive-definite. It is assumed that M i (q i ) is bounded, as well as δ i for i = 1, 2, . . . , n.
The stationary leader is given by
where q n+1 ∈ R m is the state of the leader with a constant p.
Rewriting (1) in the matrix form yields
div.formula: M(q)q + C(q, q)q + G(q) = τ + δ (3)
div.p: where
div.formula: M(q) = diag{M 1 (q 1 ), M 2 (q 2 ), . . . , M n (q n )}, C(q, q) = diag{C 1 (q 1 , q1 ), C 2 (q 2 , q2 ), . . . , C n (q n , qn )}, q = (q T 1 , q T 2 , . . . , q T n ) T , G(q) = (g 1 (q 1 ) T , g 2 (q 2 ) T , . . . , g n (q n ) T ) T , τ = (τ T 1 , τ T 2 , . . . , τ T n ) T , and δ = (δ T 1 , δ T 2 , . . . , δ T n ) T .

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, a distributed finite-time control protocol will be designed in a backstepping framework. Two auxiliary functions are introduced, which are defined by

By Lemma 1, one can conclude that the system ( 12) is finite-time stable.
Case 2: In the case of ω = 0, as V(x(t), z(t)) ≥ 0, one has

div.p: Taking the integration of (24) from t 1 to t 2 yields
Thus

div.p: With the condition that V(x(t 1 ), z(t 1 )) = 0, one obtains

div.p: Therefore, the system (12) achieves finite-time L 2 leaderfollower consensus and its finite-time L 2 gain is less than or equal to γ . The settling time is estimated by

Remark 1: In ( 15), the terms (z), ˙ (q) only contain relative distances with agents' neighbors, and it is designed in a distributed way. The term -z/[2γ 2 ] is used to ensure L 2 performance. It will disappear when external disturbances are not considered. In [36], finite-time tracking control was studied in the context of coupled two Euler-Lagrange systems in a master-slave framework. It is obvious that the controller in [36] cannot be applied to cope with a group of Euler-Lagrange systems. The interactions among agents bring big challenges. A distributed control protocol as shown in ( 15) is proposed to solve this problem. Moreover, in [36], the self-feedback terms -x and -z were included in the controller to stabilize the terms xz and z T 1 z 1 . While in this paper, such terms are dropped. Instead, two distributed terms k 0 j∈N i a ij (q iq j ) and k 2 j∈N i a ij (z iz j ) are proposed, which are effective.

Remark 2: In this paper, a stationary leader is considered. Although distributed controllers were proposed in [20]- [22] for networked Euler-Lagrange systems with a dynamical leader, asymptotical consensus was achieved. While in this paper finite-time L 2 leader-follower consensus is considered. A continuous nonsmooth function term sig(•) α contained in (q) and (z) is employed to ensure finite-time leaderfollower consensus. In [29] and [30], a disturbance compensator technique combined with adaptive control was used to eliminate the effect of external disturbances. Complete consensus or bounded consensus was achieved. Different from [29] and [30], a performance vector is defined and a finite-time L 2 controller is designed to attenuate external disturbances.

Remark 3: In [20], [21], and [30], adaptive control law was used to deal with multiple Euler-Lagrange systems with parameter uncertainties. In [40], the boundedness of the trajectory was ensured first, then a robust integral sign of the error-based decentralized control law was developed to achieve semiglobal asymptotic synchronization of uncertain Euler-Lagrange systems. Note that these papers focus on asymptotical synchronization. It is more challenging to combine adaptive control technique and finite-time stability theory to deal with model uncertainties. Thus, the model parameters are required to be known in this paper. It is interesting to further study finite-time synchronization of networked Euler-Lagrange systems with parameter uncertainties.

Remark 4: It should be pointed out that finite-time distributed controllers have been proposed in [23], [24], and [29] to deal with the consensus problem in the existence of a dynamical leader. Second-order observers were designed in [23] and [24]. However, the results in [23] are only valid for linear multiagent systems. Moreover, the upper bound of the settling time was not given in [23] and [24] as homogeneous theory was used in [23] and [24]. The sliding terminal mode control approach was used in [29]. It is obvious that the method based on slide mode control for the disturbance elimination is different from ours. Moreover, the chattering phenomenon may occur.
Remark 5: If a dynamical leader
div.formula: qn+1 = f (q n+1 , qn+1 )
div.p: is considered in this paper, the following controller:
div.formula: τ i = M i (q) i (z) + ˙ i (q) - 1 2γ 2 z i + qn+1 + C(q i , qi )q + G(q i ), i = 1, 2, . . . , n(27)
div.p: will be designed. It should be noted that the controller ( 27) is not in a distributed way. This is because the leader's information qn+1 should be known to every follower. In order to better reflect the collaboration mechanism of networked systems, a distributed controller is needed, which brings a big challenge for tracking a dynamical leader in finite time. This paper solves the leader-follower finite-time consensus with a stationary leader. The case with a dynamical leader will be considered in our future study. Remark 6: The proposed distributed finite-time L 2 consensus protocol for multiple Euler-Lagrange systems can be easily obtained by choosing some parameters. More importantly, it is not necessary to solve the linear matrix inequality to design a robust controller [34], [38]. Therefore, the proposed control protocol is applicable.
Remark 7: The derivative of (q) will be infinite when q i = q j due to 0 < α < 1. To avoid this singularity problem, in simulation we adopt the following form of (dsig(x) α /dt):
div.formula: dsig(x) α dt = ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ α|x| α-1 ẋ, |x| ≥ η and ẋ = 0 α| | α-1 ẋ, |x| < η and ẋ = 0 0, ẋ = 0(28)
div.p: where η and are both small positive constants. The distributed control protocol ( 15) is able to ensure the finite-time L 2 stability of the system (12). When external disturbances are not taken into account, the following result will give a simpler control protocol with smaller feedback gains k 0 and k 3 .

Theorem 2: Under Assumption 1, consider the networked Euler-Lagrange system (12) without external disturbances. If a distributed control protocol is designed as τ = M(q) (z) + ˙ (q) + C(q, q)q + G(q) (29) then the system ( 12) is finite-time stable provided that k 0 and k 2 are not less than (1/[2λ min (L 1 )]). Proof: Choose the same candidate Lyapunov function as Theorem 1. Similar to Theorem 1, if k 0 and k 2 are not less than (1/[2λ min (L 1 )]), one gets
div.formula: V ≤ 1 2 -k 0 λ min (L 1 ) x T x + 1 2 -k 2 λ min (L 1 ) z T z -k 1 n i=1 n+1 j=1 a ij x T i sig(x i -x j ) α -k 2 n i=1 n+1 j=1 a ij z T i sig(z i -z j ) α ≤ -k 1 n i=1 n+1 j=1 a ij x T i sig(x i -x j ) α -k 2 n i=1 n+1 j=1 a ij z T i sig(z i -z j ) α . (30
div.p: Then one concludes that the system (12) without external disturbances is finite-time stable. Remark 8: The distributed control protocol τ in Theorem 2 is simpler than the one in Theorem 1. It can be seen that the term -z/[2γ 2 ] is utilized to obtain the finite-time L 2 performance. When external disturbances are not considered, such a term is not needed. Furthermore, the parameters k 0 and k 2 are only related to the topology of networked Euler-Lagrange systems, which are smaller than the ones in Theorem 1.

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS
div.p: To show the effectiveness of the theoretical results. A network of seven two-link manipulators is considered. A single two-link manipulator is depicted in Fig. 1, whose dynamics is given by
div.formula: M 11 M 12 M 21 M 22 qi1 qi2 + -cq i2 -c(q i1 + qi2 ) cq i1 0 qi1 qi2 = τ i1 τ i2
div.p: where M 11 = a 1 + 2a 3 cos(q i2 ) + 2a 4 cos(q i2 ), M 12 = M 21 = a 2 + 2a 3 cos(q i2 ) + 2a 4 cos(q i2 ), M 22 = a 2 , c = a 3 sin(q i2 )a 4 cos(q i2 ), c = a 3 sin(q i2 )a 4 cos(q i2 ), a 1 = I 1 + m 1 l 2 c1 + I e + m e l 2 ce + m e l 2 1 , a 2 = I e + m e l 2 ce , a 3 = m e l 1 l ce cos(θ e ), and a 4 = m e l 1 l ce sin(θ e ). In simulation, as in [24], set m 1 = 1, l 1 = 1, m e = 2, θ e = (π/6), I 1 = 0.12, l c1 = 0.5, I e = 0.25, and l ce = 0.6. The followers' initially states are q
and q 6 (0) = (96 • , 0 • ) T . The leader's state is q 7 (0) = (60 • , 30 • ) T . The communication topology is visualized by Fig. 2. By computation, λ min (L 1 ) = 0.1088.

First, we consider a network of seven two-link manipulators without external disturbances. With the controller proposed in Theorem 2, it can be calculated that k 0 , k 2 ≥ 4.59. While if Theorem 1 is applied, the feedback gains need to be settling time satisfies T ≤ 3.96 s. Figs. 7-10 depict time evolutions of joint angles and their derivatives in the presence of external disturbances, from which the settling time is 1.67 s.

Third, to further show the effect of the finite-time L 2 index γ , three different values are chosen. Fig. 11 depicts the time evolutions of S(t) on logarithmic scale with different γ . One can see that although S(t) with a smaller γ has a better performance that the other two, it will result in a large amplitude of the controller (15). In practice, the system may not endure such large control inputs. A balance between the controller design and the performance is needed to be taken into account.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: Finite-time L 2 leader-follower consensus of networked Euler-Lagrange systems with external disturbances is studied in this paper. A backstepping framework for distributed finitetime L 2 consensus is established. Then a distributed control protocol is designed to solve the leader-follower consensus problem of networked Euler-Lagrange systems with a stationary leader in finite time. A criterion is derived to ensure leader-follower consensus in finite time and the finite-time L 2 gain is less or equal than the prescribed value. Moreover, the settling time is also estimated. While the settling time depends on the initial states of all followers. However, in a general case, the initial states may be unknown. It is difficult to estimate the settling time. The fixed-time consensus problem of multiple Euler-Lagrange systems therefore is more challenging. One the other hand, the network topology may be time-varying. A class of Markovian jump systems provides a good way to model time-varying systems [41], [42]. It is interesting to model networked Euler-Lagrange systems with switching topologies as Markovian jump systems. Both will be included in our future study.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Key Research and Development Program of China under Grant 2016YFB0303401, in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61773163, in part by the Fundamental Research Funds for Central Universities under Grant 222201717006, in part the by Young Elite Scientists Sponsorship Program by CAST under Grant 2016QNRC001, in part by the Natural Science Foundation of Shanghai under Grant 17ZR1444600, and in part by the 111 Project under Grant B17017. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor H. R. Karimi.

Ziqiang Lang received the B.S. degree in automatic control from Shenyang University, Shenyang, China, the M.Sc. degree in automatic control from Northeastern University, Shenyang, and the Ph.D. degree in automatic control and systems engineering from the University of Sheffield, Sheffield, U.K.

He is currently the Chair Professor of Complex Systems Analysis and Design with the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, University of Sheffield. His current research interests include theories and methods for complex systems modeling, analysis, design, signal processing, and the application of these to resolving various engineering problems, including smart structures and systems, civil and mechanical structure vibration control, structural health monitoring, and condition monitoring and fault diagnosis for engineering systems.
